title: The Black Keys - Rubber Factory (2004)
description:
Amazon.co.uk Review
Opening with the slide guitar-driven &quot;When the Lights Go Out&quot;, Rubber Factory starts as it means to go on Ã¢â‚¬â€œ this is blues that sticks to its guns and does a damn fine job of it. And there's more to recommend it than simply the lovely lo-fi production (Jack White eat yer heart out) Ã¢â‚¬â€œ there's conviction in the performance and strong songs to back it up. In a genre that, these days, has a tendency to slip into dreary clichÃƒÂ©, The Black Keys should be applauded for keeping things interesting.

So this is a blues album Ã¢â‚¬â€œ to dress it up as anything else would be to miss its point. But that shouldn't put off the casual listener. As well as the more trad-sounding opener, and tracks such as &quot;Stack Shot Billy&quot; (whose guitar wouldn't sound out of place on a John Lee Hooker record), you get the beautiful, mournful &quot;The Lengths&quot; and rockers such as &quot;All Hands Against His Own&quot; and the album's rousing closer, &quot;Till I Get My Way&quot;. All in all, proof that the blues can still be relevant today, even if a sizeable proportion of its originators are now no longer with us. --Marc Bloomfield

Album Description
Rubber Factory is the second album from the acclaimed guitar and drum, delta blues-infused rock duo from Akron, Ohio, The Black Keys. Their first release, Thickfreakness, was a massive hit in the UK and got great reviews in the music press. 

58MB, mp3@192
